                                                                                                                                           THE ANIMOMETER.
                                                                                                                                           construction      of    this instrument
                                                                                                                          THE        may be as follows.              Let A B C D
                                                                                                                          EFGH,    (Plate II. Fig. i.) be an open
                                                                                                                          frame of wood, firmly supported by the
                                                                                                                          post P.          In the    cross   pieces      I    and       L   is
                                                                                                                          moved        an     horizontal          axis       QJV1,          by
                                                                                                                          means       of   the four fails, a b, c d,           e   f,   gh,
                                                                                                                          exposed to the wind in a proper direction.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-02 19:24 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018448970
                                                                                                                          Upon this axis is fixed a cone of wood
                                                                                                                          MNO, upon which, as the fails move
                                                                                                                          round,     weight S is raised, by a string
                                                                                                                                       a
                                                                                                                          on its surface, proceeding from the small
                                                                                                                          to the largest end            N O.       Upon the great
                                                                                                                           end, or base        of the   cone, is fixed a ratchet-
                                                                                                                           wheel I         K, in    whose teeth falls the click
                                                                                                                           X,    to prevent a retrograde motion from,
                                                                                                                           the depending wheel.
                                                                                                                                It   is easy to perceive, from the construe-*
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                           tion of this machine, that it is adapted to
                                                                                                                           estimate the variable force of the wind,
                                                                                                                                                                                   because

                                                                                                                          ,0                  RATIONAL
                                                                                                                          because the force              of      the weight       will   con
                                                                                                                          tinually increase            as    the string advances on
                                                                                                                          the conical surface, by acting at a greater
                                                                                                                          distance from the axis ; and therefore                             if
                                                                                                                          such a weight be put on the smallest part
                                                                                                                          at   M,        as   will just     keep the machine               in
                                                                                                                          equilibrio with the weakest wind ;                         as   the
                                                                                                                          wind becomes stronger, the weight will
                                                                                                                          be raised in proportion, from S towards
                                                                                                                          R}        and the diameter               of   the base     of   the
                                                                                                                          cone       N O,       may be so large,             in compari
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-02 19:24 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018448970
                                                                                                                          son       of   that   of    the smaller end or axis at
                                                                                                                          M,        that the strongest wind shall but just
                                                                                                                          raise the weight to the great end.
                                                                                                                               Let the diameter of the axis, for exam
                                                                                                                          ple, be to that            of the      base   of the   cone    N O,
                                                                                                                          9S    i    to 28. Then          if S     be   a   weight of one
                                                                                                                          pound on the axis at                   M, it will      be equiva
                                                                                                                          lent to 28 pounds, or one-fourth of a hun
                                                                                                                          dred weight, when raised to the greatest
                                                                                                                          end.           Therefore,         if    when the wind is
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          weakest it support one pound on the axis

                                                                                                                                           R   AT    I O N AL
                                                                                                                            But the great use of the barometer,
                                                                                                                          when well constructed, is that of predicting
                                                                                                                          the future state     of the   weather, for several
                                                                                                                          hours,   and.    sometimes days,         preceding ;
                                                                                                                          though not to        a   certainty,     yet in many
                                                                                                                          instances to a great degree           of probability   ;
                                                                                                                          in order to obtain this desireable end,            ob->
                                                                                                                          serve the following rules.
                                                                                                                             First, The riling of the mercury presages
                                                                                                                          in general, fair weather; and its falling,
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-02 19:24 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018448970
                                                                                                                          foul weather.        2. In very hot weather, the
                                                                                                                          falling of the mercury foreshows thunder,
                                                                                                                          3. In winter, the rising portends frost ;
                                                                                                                          and in a continued frost it foretells show,
                                                                                                                          4. When foul weather happens soon after
                                                                                                                          the falling of the mercury, expect but
                                                                                                                           little of it;   and so, on thecontrary,         of fair
                                                                                                                           weather.       5. But when the mercury con
                                                                                                                           tinues to rife for some time before the foul
                                                                                                                           weather is over,        expect a continuance          of
                                                                                                                           fair weather to follow.              6. In fair wea
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                           ther, when the mercury continues to fall
                                                                                                                           before rain comes, then expect           a   great deal
                                                                                                                                                                                 of

                                                                                                                                             RECREATIONS.                                       23.
                                                                                                                          tos   it ;   and probably high winds.                     7.    The
                                                                                                                          unsettled motion of the mercury                           denotes
                                                                                                                          uncertain or changeable weather.
                                                                                                                                It    appears from these observations,                    that
                                                                                                                          it    is not so much the height                  of the mer
                                                                                                                          cury that indicates the weather,                     as   its mo
                                                                                                                          tion up or down. Therefore                            to know
                                                                                                                          whether the mercury be actually rising or
                                                                                                                          falling, observe the following rules.                           1 .   If
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-02 19:24 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018448970
                                                                                                                          the surface            of   the mercury be convex, it is
                                                                                                                          then rising.            2.   If the surface     be concave,           it
                                                                                                                          is then sinking.               3.    If the   surface be plain,
                                                                                                                          or rather          a   little convex, it may be consi
                                                                                                                          dered as stationary.                   If the   tube be small,
                                                                                                                          shake        it, and        if the   air be growing heaviei
                                                                                                                          it will       rise about        half the tenth of an inch,
                                                                                                                          and        if it   be growing lighter           it will sink the
                                                                                                                          same space,
                                                                                                                               The      great utility          of   the common baro
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          meter has induced many persons to invent
                                                                                                                          others, in which                the rise and fall          of    the
                                                                                                                          mercury,           and consequently the alterations
                                                                                                                                                          C 4                                   of

                                                                                                                          24               RATIONAL
                                                                                                                          the atmosphere, or the height     of   places,
                                                                                                                          may be more easily observed ; such as the

                                                                                                                          pendant barometers, Sec. which are in ge

                                                                                                                                       DEFINITIONS.
                                                                                                                           I.TTYDROLOGY                           is   that part     of
                                                                                                                                       phisiology       which          explains      the

                                                                                                                          shows the manner of conveying water from

                                                                                                                                               THE PUMP.
                                                                                                                          ' I 'HE       pump is at once the most com
                                                                                                                                    mon and most useful of all hydraulic
                                                                                                                          instruments.            Of      pumps         there are three
                                                                                                                          sorts,      the sucking,             forcing, and lifting
                                                                                                                          pump.
                                                                                                                                A   B (PI.      IV. Fig.2.) is the pipe or
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-02 19:24 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018448970
                                                                                                                          barrel      of   a   common sucking pump, C D
                                                                                                                          the piston or bucket,                E F two        valves that
                                                                                                                          open        upward.        When the handle of the
                                                                                                                          pump is put down it raises the bucket, and
                                                                                                                          the valve        F    shuts.     The      water above the
                                                                                                                          bucket being raised,             a   vacuum is left under
                                                                                                                          it,    and the external air pressing on the wa
                                                                                                                          ter in the well          M N,        raises   it   up, through
                                                                                                                          the hole B,            and lifting up the valve               E,
                                                                                                                          enters the barrel of the pump.                       The han
                                                                                                                          dle    of   the pump being               then raised,        the
                                                                                                                          bucket descends,               the valve      F    opens,    and
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          lets      the water ascend above the bucket.
                                                                                                                          The       pressure    of the water       at the same time
                                                                                                                                                                                      shuts

                                                                                                                          62             RATIONAL
                                                                                                                          shuts the valve    E,   so   that it cannot return
                                                                                                                          through B.      The handle being again      press
                                                                                                                          ed down the bucket is again raised,           and
                                                                                                                          more water       ascends through B.        So that
                                                                                                                          at every stroke    of   the handle, the water in
                                                                                                                          the barrel is increased, till at last it runs
                                                                                                                          out at the pipe    H.
                                                                                                                            If the bucket     be more than 30 or 32 feet
                                                                                                                          from the surface of the water in the well, it
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-02 19:24 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018448970
                                                                                                                          will   not ascend to the bucket, for the pres
                                                                                                                          sure   of   the atmosphere, as we have before
                                                                                                                          observed,     is but equal to 32 feet    of water.
                                                                                                                          The weight      the bucket lifts at each stroke,
                                                                                                                          is equal to a column of water whose diame
                                                                                                                          ter is that of the bore of the pump and its
                                                                                                                          height M H. It is therefore of no conse
                                                                                                                          quence where the bucket is placed,           with
                                                                                                                          regard to the weight      of water. To    balance
                                                                                                                          that weight the handle           should be made'
                                                                                                                          heavy.      The piston or bucket must      be sur
                                                                                                                          rounded with leather, that it may exactly
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          fit the bore of the pump, at the same time
                                                                                                                          it moves freely up      and down.     The valves
                                                                                                                                                                        also

                                                                                                                                       RECREATIONS.                               63
                                                                                                                          also     should      move free,           and   shut quite
                                                                                                                          close.  The smaller the bore of the pump,
                                                                                                                          the easier it will work ; but the wider it is,
                                                                                                                          and the longer the stroke of the handle,
                                                                                                                          the more water it will raise.
                                                                                                                             The forcing          pump is constructed as fol
                                                                                                                          lows     :   A B (PI. IV. Fig. 3.)              is the bar
                                                                                                                          rel standing in the water of the well at B.
                                                                                                                          C is the piston,              and    G    the handle:    C
                                                                                                                          is a solid piece, without any valve, as no
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-02 19:24 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018448970
                                                                                                                          water is to pass thro' it            :   this piece should
                                                                                                                          be carefully leathered, and made to fit the
                                                                                                                          barrel       so    exactly,    that in its motion nei
                                                                                                                          ther water nor air may pass between them.
                                                                                                                          At a distance below, as at D, a valve is fix
                                                                                                                          ed.       Between this and the lowest situation
                                                                                                                          of the       piston C, there goes off a pipe          H, in
                                                                                                                          which is fixed a valve at E.

                                                                                                                          into the space          CD;         and when the piston
                                                                                                                                                                                is

                                                                                                                              F  (which may be placed at any distance

                                                                                                                               Take      a   pack of cards that consists            of

                                                                                                                          when the three heaps are finished, ask him
                                                                                                                          at what number, from 1 ,'to 27, he will
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-02 19:25 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018448970

                                                                                                                          it   then is.      Then look           at the heap through
                                                                                                                          the glass, and       if the        first   of the three num
                                                                                                                          bers which          stands against that number             it
                                                                                                                          is to appear at be     put that heap at top ;
                                                                                                                                                     1   ,
                                                                                                                          if   the number be 2, put it in the middle ;
                                                                                                                          and    if it   be 3, put    it     at bottom.      Then di
                                                                                                                          vide the cards into three heaps, in the
                                                                                                                          fame manner,          a second             and a third time,
                                                                                                                          and his card        will   then be at the number he
                                                                                                                          chose.

                                                                                                                                                                       The

                                                                                                                                   RECREATIONS.                    279
                                                                                                                            The foregoing recreations with the cards
                                                                                                                          will be found sufficient to explain all others
                                                                                                                          of a similar nature, that have or may be
                                                                                                                          made, the number of which is very great.
                                                                                                                          To   perform   these we have described re
                                                                                                                          quires no great practice ; the two princi
                                                                                                                          pal points are, the making the pass in a
                                                                                                                          dextrous manner, and a certain address
                                                                                                                          by which you influence    a   person to draw
                                                                                                                          the card you present.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-02 19:25 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018448970
                                                                                                                            Those recreations that are performed
                                                                                                                          by the long card are, in general, the most
                                                                                                                          easy, but they are confined to a pack      of
                                                                                                                          cards that is ready prepared ;      whereas,
                                                                                                                          those that depend on making the pass, may
                                                                                                                          be performed with any pack that is        of
                                                                                                                          fered.
